title: Phase 1-Clinical Validation
reflection: Through early interviews with orthopedic surgeons and patients, we confirmed that periprosthetic joint infection (PJI), while rare, causes devastating consequences. These conversations grounded our project in a real and urgent medical need, and guided us to focus on biofilm clearance as a clinically meaningful goal

data.title: Understanding Real Clinical Needs_Dr. Shang-Wen Tsai
data.name: Dr. Shang-Wen Tsai — Orthopedic Surgeon, Taipei Veterans General Hospital
data.topic: Periprosthetic Joint Infection (PJI) in Total Knee Arthroplasty
data.story: ① Clinical Validation — Understanding Real Clinical Needs
text: 🔹 Before the Interview

At the start of our project, we wanted to verify whether our idea of using enzyme-based treatment for biofilm infections truly addressed an unmet clinical need. We approached Dr. Tsai, an orthopedic surgeon experienced in total knee arthroplasty (TKA), to understand the real-world challenges of PJI, its frequency, and current treatment limitations.
🔹 During the Interview

Key takeaways from Dr. Tsai’s sharing: fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - PJI cases are rare but catastrophic — once infection occurs, it leads to prolonged hospitalization, multiple surgeries, and major psychological and financial burdens. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Diagnosis is complex, often relying on invasive sampling or surgical exposure rather than imaging. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Current treatments are surgical by default — infected prostheses must often be removed or revised; antibiotics alone are insufficient. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Antibiotic resistance and biofilm persistence are major obstacles to recovery.
🔹 After the Interview (Key Insights)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - PJI’s low incidence but high severity confirmed that our problem choice was clinically meaningful. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - The fact that surgical removal is the only reliable solution highlighted the need for less invasive alternatives. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We realized that orthopedic surgeons value any approach that could shorten recovery time and reduce surgical recurrence, even if it complements rather than replaces surgery.
🔹 Action (Integration into the Project)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We validated our project’s clinical relevance — ensuring our enzyme-based design truly targeted a significant medical pain point. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Based on Dr. Tsai’s input, we refined our project scope to focus on biofilm clearance within prosthetic joints rather than general wound infections. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - His emphasis on treatment realism inspired us to design an adjunct therapy model, combining enzymatic degradation with antibiotics instead of positioning it as a full surgical replacement. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - This interview became the foundation for our subsequent consultations with Dr. Lin Cheng-Li (NCKU) and infectious disease specialists, forming the clinical starting point of our Human Practice storyline.

data.title: Understanding Real Clinical Needs_Dr. Cheng-Li Lin
data.name: Dr. Cheng-Li Lin — Orthopedic Surgeon, National Cheng Kung University Hospital
data.topic: Postoperative Biofilm Infections in Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA)
data.story: ① Clinical Validation — Understanding Real Clinical Needs
text: 🔹 Before the Interview

Following our first discussion with Dr. Tsai, we aimed to gain a deeper understanding of how biofilm-related infections are actually managed in surgery and what clinical gaps still exist. We invited Dr. Lin, who has over 20 years of experience treating orthopedic infections, to discuss how infections are diagnosed, what challenges doctors face, and whether a low-invasive, biofilm-targeted therapy like ours could have real clinical value.
🔹 During the Interview

Key insights shared by Dr. Lin: fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Infection management is stratified: fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Acute infections can sometimes be managed by debridement and antibiotics. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Chronic infections often require prosthesis removal, bone cement replacement, and multiple surgeries. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Biofilm diagnosis is imprecise: detection relies mainly on surgical observation and culture, with no effective imaging or biomarkers. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Antibiotic penetration remains limited, and chronic infections often relapse despite long antibiotic courses. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Patient suffering is immense: repeated surgeries, long recovery, and risk of sepsis or amputation. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - On new approaches: Dr. Lin was open to the idea of bacterial or enzymatic therapy, but cautioned that E. coli may trigger immune reactions and safety doubts. Using non-pathogenic probiotics or controlled enzyme delivery could improve acceptance. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Suggested features of an ideal therapy: safety, local delivery, and slow release of enzymes to sustain activity.
🔹 After the Interview (Key Insights)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - This conversation clarified the clinical workflow of infection management and the limitations of current methods. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We learned that a gradual, sustained release system would be more realistic than a single injection. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Dr. Lin’s concerns about biosafety and immunogenicity helped us identify the next step — consulting infectious disease doctors and biosafety experts. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - His suggestion to consider probiotic carriers or encapsulated delivery broadened our design perspective.
🔹 Action (Integration into the Project)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We adjusted our technical direction to emphasize controlled enzyme release rather than live bacterial persistence. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We planned to evaluate alternative chassis (e.g., E. coli Nissle, GRAS strains) and biosafety frameworks to ensure clinical feasibility. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Dr. Lin’s insights guided us to interview infectious disease specialists (Dr. Chen Po-Lin) and biosafety experts (Prof. Tang Ching-Hao) in the next stage. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - His emphasis on patient experience and infection recurrence reinforced our commitment to design a treatment that supports surgical recovery, rather than replacing surgery entirely.

data.title: Patient Perspective on Real-World Challenges＿Ms. Lin
data.name: Ms. Lin — Patient (62 years old), underwent total knee arthroplasty and experienced infection and recovery
data.topic: Patient experience with post-surgical infection and rehabilitation
data.story: ① Clinical Validation — Patient Perspective on Real-World Challenges
text: 🔹 Before the Interview

To complement doctors’ perspectives on PJI, we wanted to understand how infection and recovery actually feel from a patient’s point of view — both physically and emotionally. We interviewed Ms. Lin, who had undergone total knee replacement and later faced wound complications and extended recovery. Her story offered a human dimension to our understanding of the problem we were trying to solve.
🔹 During the Interview

Main points shared by Ms. Lin: fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - She experienced severe pain and limited mobility after surgery, requiring months of rehabilitation. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - The wound healing process was slow and complex, involving repeated dressing changes, disinfection, and worries about infection recurrence. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - She described daily difficulties: climbing stairs, standing up, and walking required gradual retraining and constant pain management. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Infection fear was a major source of anxiety — even small wounds caused worry about reinfection or needing another surgery. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Rehabilitation required strong willpower and social support; transportation and follow-up care were major burdens for older patients.
🔹 After the Interview (Key Insights)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - The interview revealed the emotional and logistical burden patients face even after a “successful” surgery. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Reinfection risk and prolonged recovery make patients highly sensitive to safety and convenience — any new treatment must minimize hospitalization and pain. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Her story emphasized that for patients, “non-invasive” means not only avoiding surgery, but also reducing the fear and uncertainty surrounding infection recurrence.
🔹 Action (Integration into the Project)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We integrated this perspective into our Human Practices design framework, recognizing that real-world success requires both clinical effectiveness and patient trust. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - It inspired us to adopt a patient-centered narrative in our outreach materials — focusing on recovery, safety, and comfort rather than just biotechnology. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Ms. Lin’s experience also guided how we communicated with the public: we began emphasizing the real impact of biofilm infections through relatable stories, later used in our educational Reels and workshop storytelling. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Her case reaffirmed that our project should aim to reduce secondary surgeries and support smoother recovery, shaping how we described Byefilm’s future clinical role.

title: Phase 2-Public Understanding, The biofilm outside TKA
reflection: Our dialogue with humanities scholars and clinicians revealed a large public knowledge gap about biofilms and synthetic biology. This phase helped us realize that scientific innovation must go hand-in-hand with transparent communication and ethical framing, leading us to design outreach activities that make science approachable.

data.title: Identifying Knowledge Gaps and Societal Concerns_Prof. I-Jun Li
data.name: Prof. I-Jun Li — Department of Medical Humanities and Social Medicine, National Cheng Kung University
data.topic: Public perception, medical ethics, and social understanding of biotechnology
data.story: ② Public Understanding — Identifying Knowledge Gaps and Societal Concerns
text: 🔹 Before the Interview

After learning from clinicians about the severity of biofilm infections, we realized that introducing a biotechnology-based therapy to society would also require public trust and ethical awareness. We invited Prof. Li to help us understand how people perceive new medical biotechnologies and how teams like ours could responsibly communicate scientific ideas to the general public.
🔹 During the Interview

Key insights from Prof. Li: fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Most people have never heard of “biofilm”, even though it plays a major role in chronic infections. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Public attitudes toward biotechnology are dominated by concern about safety — especially regarding genetically modified organisms and their use in humans. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Language and framing matter: terms like “engineered bacteria” or “modified E. coli” may sound alarming unless clearly contextualized. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Effective communication should link science to familiar human experiences, such as infection, healing, and hygiene, instead of abstract molecular terms. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Scientists should view themselves as educators and collaborators, not only inventors — bridging the gap between laboratory innovation and patient trust.
🔹 After the Interview (Key Insights)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We discovered a large knowledge gap between scientific and public understanding. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - This conversation shifted our mindset: public engagement is not just outreach, but an essential part of responsible innovation. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We realized that explaining what biofilms are and why they matter would be crucial to the success and acceptance of our project.
🔹 Action (Integration into the Project)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We redesigned our science communication strategy to simplify complex concepts through accessible language and visuals. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - This led to our later initiatives — creating educational Reels, designing a biofilm workshop for high school students, and developing an interactive educational game. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We adopted Prof. Li’s advice on framing: instead of emphasizing “genetic modification,” we highlighted our work as an effort to make infection treatment safer and more precise. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - His input also influenced our internal reflection: every outreach or design decision should consider ethical transparency and social impact, becoming a key part of our Integrated Human Practices framework.

data.title: Connecting Clinical Ethics and Social Concerns_Dr. Chao-Kai Hsu
data.name: Dr. Chao-Kai Hsu — Dermatologist, National Cheng Kung University Hospital
data.topic: Clinical insight on immune-related diseases and reflections on public perception of biotechnology
data.story: ② Public Understanding — Connecting Clinical Ethics and Social Concerns
text: 🔹 Before the Interview

After identifying the public’s safety concerns through our conversation with Prof. Li, we sought perspectives from clinicians who regularly manage patients with immune disorders. Dr. Hsu, known for his expertise in rare genetic and skin-related immune diseases (such as Epidermolysis Bullosa, or “bubble boy disease”), offered valuable insight into how clinicians balance innovation and patient safety, and how patients perceive biotechnological risk.
🔹 During the Interview

Key takeaways from Dr. Hsu’s discussion: fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Patients’ trust is built slowly — even clinically validated treatments can face hesitation if patients feel uncertain about the underlying mechanism. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - When introducing new biotech-based interventions, communication must be personalized, not overly technical. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - He shared examples where gene or enzyme therapies faced skepticism due to unclear explanations of long-term effects or biological containment. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - He emphasized that doctors serve as interpreters between scientific innovation and patient decision-making — their understanding and confidence directly shape public acceptance. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - In his experience, people fear “bioengineering” mainly because of unknown long-term risks, not because they oppose innovation itself.
🔹 After the Interview (Key Insights)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We learned that medical communication is relational — patients trust science through doctors, not just through data. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - This reinforced the idea that human connection and transparency should be core to our outreach design. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - It also reminded us that clinical acceptance and public trust depend on showing that safety and control mechanisms are as important as innovation.
🔹 Action (Integration into the Project)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We began emphasizing biosafety explanation as part of every educational activity — clearly describing how our system ensures containment and non-pathogenicity. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - In our public Reels and high-school workshop, we introduced examples of good vs. harmful bacteria to contextualize risk and safety intuitively. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - This conversation also inspired the idea of co-designing educational material with doctors, ensuring both scientific accuracy and emotional reassurance. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Finally, Dr. Hsu’s approach informed how we communicated with clinicians later — positioning Byefilm not as a risky “live bacteria therapy,” but as a carefully controlled biological aid to enhance antibiotic treatment.

title: Phase 3-Biosafety & Responsibility
reflection: Through consultations with infectious disease experts, molecular biologists, and international researchers, we learned that safety defines credibility. Their feedback transformed Byefilm from a live-bacteria concept into a biosafe enzyme-based biologic, ensuring that our innovation remains both ambitious and responsible.

data.title: Evaluating Clinical Risks and Containment Strategies
data.name: Dr. Po-Lin Chen — Infectious Disease Specialist, National Cheng Kung University Hospital
data.topic: Clinical safety concerns and biosafety principles in engineered bacteria design
data.story: ③ Biosafety & Responsibility — Evaluating Clinical Risks and Containment Strategies
text: 🔹 Before the Interview

After realizing from orthopedic interviews that doctors were concerned about immune reactions, we wanted to understand how infectious disease specialists evaluate risk when live bacteria are involved. We consulted Dr. Chen to learn what biosafety issues would arise if engineered E. coli were ever used in human tissue and how we could design our project responsibly to address those concerns.
🔹 During the Interview

Key points shared by Dr. Chen： fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - In clinical practice, E. coli and the immune system are “natural enemies.” Even non-pathogenic strains trigger inflammation via endotoxins (LPS recognized by TLR4). fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Introducing bacteria into human tissue will almost certainly cause an acute inflammatory reaction — and potential sepsis if not fully controlled. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - He warned that even foreign enzymes from non-human sources could induce allergic responses or antibody formation. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - From a biosafety standpoint, purified enzymes or non-living delivery systems would be far more acceptable clinically than live bacteria. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - In Taiwan and globally, there are few if any precedents for injecting engineered bacteria into humans outside of strict oncology trials. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - He stressed that any proposed therapy must clearly demonstrate containment, non-transfer of resistance genes, and well-defined immune profiles before discussion of clinical translation.
🔹 After the Interview (Key Insights)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - This conversation confirmed that biosafety is the critical barrier between research and real application. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We realized that our concept would not be clinically credible without a clear plan to address immune and endotoxin risks. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Dr. Chen’s emphasis on purified or non-living forms shifted our thinking from “live bacteria therapy” toward enzyme-based biologics or controlled delivery platforms.
🔹 Action (Integration into the Project)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We re-evaluated our design to include alternative chassis such as probiotics or non-living enzyme systems. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We added a biosafety consultation track within our project workflow and initiated follow-up discussions with Prof. Tang Ching-Hao on LPS and immune modification strategies. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Dr. Chen’s feedback directly led to the creation of our “Biosafety and Containment Framework,” a document summarizing design choices that minimize clinical risk. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - It also inspired a new educational angle in our public communication — explaining how synthetic biology can be safe, traceable, and ethically applied in medicine.

data.title: Evaluating Molecular Risks and Responsible Innovation
data.name: Prof. Ching-Hao Tang — Institute of Molecular Medicine, National Cheng Kung University
data.topic: Engineering safety, host–bacteria interaction, and risk mitigation strategies for live bacterial therapies
data.story: ③ Biosafety & Responsibility — Evaluating Molecular Risks and Responsible Innovation
text: 🔹 Before the Interview

After receiving biosafety concerns from Dr. Chen (Infectious Disease), we wanted to understand why live E. coli causes such strong immune reactions and what molecular or genetic strategies could make it safer. We invited Prof. Tang, who studies host–pathogen interactions, to help us evaluate the feasibility and limitations of using engineered bacteria in medical environments.
🔹 During the Interview

Prof. Tang provided deep technical insights: fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - E. coli’s diversity matters: pathogenic, commensal, and probiotic strains differ greatly in genome and virulence; even “harmless” strains can trigger sepsis if introduced into tissues or blood. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Immune risk is unavoidable — Gram-negative bacteria possess LPS, which activates TLR4 and cytokine cascades; when bacteria die or lyse, released lipid A causes the most dangerous inflammatory reaction. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Kill-switch mechanisms alone are insufficient: clinical reviewers will still question the idea of injecting live Gram-negative bacteria into humans. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - If live bacteria are ever to be used, we must provide a strong scientific rationale (e.g., persistence, targeting ability) and solid safety data. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Suggested directions: fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Consider LPS modification or deletion (e.g., msbB, lpxM mutants) to reduce toxicity. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Explore GRAS strains, non-living enzyme delivery (OMVs, hydrogels, bone cement), or encapsulated systems. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Conduct in-vitro endotoxin assays and cytokine response tests to evaluate immune activation. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - He emphasized that realistic translation requires focusing on the route most likely to pass safety review first — e.g., non-living enzyme formulations.
🔹 After the Interview (Key Insights)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Prof. Tang’s comments revealed the biological reason behind clinicians’ biosafety concerns — LPS-mediated immune response. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We learned that our design must evolve from purely engineering logic to biological and regulatory realism. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - His explanation of lipid A and systemic inflammation clarified why live E. coli therapy remains clinically unacceptable today. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We also recognized that “responsible innovation” means building for safety first, then for novelty.
🔹 Action (Integration into the Project)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We established a clear biosafety redesign roadmap, including: fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Studying LPS modification literature and detoxification mutants; fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Researching endotoxin quantification and immune activation assays (TLR4, cytokine models); fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Evaluating probiotic chassis and non-living enzyme delivery options (e.g., hydrogel release systems). fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - His advice directly influenced our technical pivot: repositioning Byefilm as a biologic adjunct therapy, emphasizing enzyme delivery rather than live-bacteria action. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - The conversation also shaped our HP narrative tone — instead of claiming “live bacterial cure,” we reframed the project around safe biological innovation with clinical accountability. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Finally, Prof. Tang’s feedback was summarized into our internal biosafety guideline, forming the backbone of our later documentation on risk assessment and containment.

data.title: Learning from International Clinical Experience
data.name: Dr. M — Scientist at Locus Biosciences, expert in live bacterial therapeutics
data.topic: Engineering design, safety prioritization, and lessons from clinical trials of bacterial therapies
data.story: ③ Biosafety & Responsibility — Learning from International Clinical Experience
text: 🔹 Before the Interview

After consulting local clinicians and biosafety experts, we wanted to look beyond Taiwan and learn from international teams that had actually advanced engineered bacteria into clinical trials. We reached out to Dr. M from Locus Biosciences, a biotech company that developed engineered E. coli for therapeutic use. The goal was to understand what challenges caused their clinical program to fail and what lessons we could apply to make our own design safer and more realistic.
🔹 During the Interview

Dr. M provided critical real-world insights: fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Safety comes first — always. The number one priority in developing live therapeutics is not efficiency or novelty, but predictable containment and non-toxicity. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Vector stability is essential. In clinical settings, antibiotics cannot be used to maintain plasmids, which means payloads (such as enzymes or kill-switches) can easily be lost. → His key advice: Integrate all functional genes into the bacterial genome to ensure stability and eliminate antibiotic-resistance markers. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Antibiotic resistance is strictly prohibited in any product that enters the human body — regulators will reject constructs that retain resistance genes. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - In vivo colonization is unpredictable. Even well-engineered strains may fail to survive or act at the intended site, which was a major reason for Locus’s project termination. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - He also discussed ethical and experimental alternatives, suggesting in-vitro and invertebrate models (such as larvae infection assays) as safer and faster routes to validate biofilm-clearing ability before animal or human testing. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Above all, he reminded us that clinical translation requires a credible story of safety and feasibility, not just experimental success.
🔹 After the Interview (Key Insights)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - This conversation grounded our biosafety thinking in real industry experience, showing that many promising designs fail due to safety oversights, not scientific weakness. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We understood that regulatory approval depends on eliminating antibiotic markers, ensuring genetic stability, and demonstrating strict containment. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Dr. M’s explanation of plasmid loss and colonization variability helped us recognize how fragile engineered systems become once removed from lab conditions. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - The conversation also validated our direction toward non-living, enzyme-based biologics — aligning innovation with responsibility.
🔹 Action (Integration into the Project)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We implemented Dr. M’s suggestions into concrete project decisions: fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Shifted to genomic integration of our kill-switch and enzyme modules to avoid plasmid instability. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Removed antibiotic-resistance markers from our constructs to comply with future biosafety standards. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Began designing endotoxin-free enzyme delivery models instead of relying solely on live-cell action. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - His discussion also inspired our team to adopt international safety practices into our documentation, referencing FDA/EMA biosafety principles. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We incorporated the larvae model idea into our research proposal for future biofilm validation — providing a realistic, ethical step between in-vitro and animal testing. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Most importantly, this exchange shaped our overall mindset: innovation must be paired with humility and precaution — a philosophy we later described in our wiki as “responsible synthetic biology.”

title: Phase 4-Education & Communication
reflection: Inspired by the public’s curiosity and concern, we turned reflection into action — developing workshops, Reels, and interactive games to explain the hidden world of biofilms. This phase taught us that education is not an afterthought, but an integral part of responsible biotechnology. #

data.title: Bridging Science and Society

data.story: Science communication, public education, and responsible outreach
text: 🔹 Before the Educational Activities

After identifying the public knowledge gap and biosafety concerns from earlier interviews, we realized that scientific innovation alone was not enough — we had to translate biofilm science into something understandable, visual, and engaging. We designed a series of educational actions to: 1. Make the concept of biofilms accessible to students and the general public. 2. Improve public literacy about biotechnology safety. 3. Learn how to communicate science more effectively through interaction.
🔹 During the Activities

1. Biofilm Workshop for High School Students fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Introduced iGEM and basic synthetic biology through interactive discussions and an ice-breaker game. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Conducted hands-on experiments simulating biofilm growth and antibiotic testing. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Guided students in brainstorming “mini iGEM projects” to help them think like scientists. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Feedback showed that many participants had never heard of biofilms before, confirming our earlier findings. 2. Popular Science Reels (Instagram Educational Series) fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Produced a 30-part short video series simplifying topics such as: fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - What are biofilms and why are they harmful? fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - How do antibiotics fail inside them? fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - How can synthetic biology help solve this? fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Each video used concise narration and visuals to target audiences aged 15–35. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Reels became a key tool for reaching audiences beyond academic circles. 3. Educational Game — “Biofilm Breakdown” fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Co-developed with the Dry Lab team to gamify enzyme–biofilm interactions. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Players learn how biofilms form, what enzymes do, and how strategies matter for treatment. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - The game helped demonstrate the complexity of infection treatment through fun and systems thinking.
🔹 After the Activities (Key Insights)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We confirmed that educational design can close the communication gap identified in earlier stages. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Students and audiences became more confident discussing biofilms and synthetic biology once concepts were linked to real-life examples. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Our team also improved our science storytelling skills — learning how to frame content ethically and clearly for non-scientists. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Education was not only outreach; it became part of our responsible innovation process, helping us listen, adapt, and respond to society.
🔹 Action (Integration into the Project)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Education became an official branch of our IHP plan — every outreach activity was tied to an insight from prior interviews (e.g., Prof. Li’s framing, Dr. Hsu’s safety messaging). fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - The workshop and reels directly addressed the public’s top concern (“Is this safe?”) by explaining biosafety principles in approachable ways. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - The educational game served as both an internal training tool and an external outreach product, reinforcing understanding through interaction. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - These actions helped us cultivate a two-way dialogue with society — transforming communication from explanation into co-learning. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Most importantly, this stage showed that responsible innovation must involve education, not as promotion, but as social engagement and empathy.

title: Phase 5-Translation & Future Application
reflection: Engaging with technology transfer mentors and regulatory experts allowed us to envision Byefilm beyond iGEM — as a potential biologic adjunct to antibiotic therapy. This stage reminded us that true innovation requires not only creativity, but continuity — connecting the lab to the real world through feasibility and foresight.

data.title: Defining Product Direction and Feasibility
data.name: Prof. Shih-Feng Chiu — Deputy Director, NCKU Industry-Academia Innovation Center

data.story: ⑤ Translation & Future Application — Defining Product Direction and Feasibility
text: 🔹 Before the Interview

As our design matured, we wanted to understand what it would take to translate an iGEM project into a viable biotech innovation. We reached out to Prof. Chiu for advice on how early-stage biotechnology can position itself within the regulatory and industrial ecosystem — especially since our project sits between drug and medical device categories.
🔹 During the Interview

Key takeaways from Prof. Chiu’s discussion: fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - The project must first clarify what kind of product it is — “biologic,” “drug,” or “medical device,” because each has different approval pathways. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Suggested referring to TFDA and FDA drug/device definitions early to design around the appropriate category. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Emphasized the need to build technical credibility and patent strategy before seeking investment. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Recommended presenting the project’s value in simple terms: “a biologic that assists antibiotics to clear infections.” fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Advised against emphasizing “live bacteria” in public documents; instead, focus on enzymatic innovation and safety. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Urged the team to visualize the product pipeline — from lab testing → formulation → safety validation → IP filing → startup incubation.
🔹 After the Interview (Key Insights)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We learned that positioning defines not only how regulators view the product, but also how investors and collaborators perceive it. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - His suggestion to use the term “biologic adjunct therapy” gave us a realistic framing between “research prototype” and “medical product.” fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - We realized that translation starts with clarity — knowing what problem we solve and who can use it first.
🔹 Action (Integration into the Project)

fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Adopted “biologic adjunct to antibiotic therapy” as our official project positioning. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Began documenting regulatory definitions (TFDA/FDA) and mapping out potential classification routes. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - Used Prof. Chiu’s framework to build our technology-to-market roadmap for internal planning. fa-solid fa-graudation-cap - His advice directly shaped our proposal for the Dream Come True (圓夢計畫) and later innovation programs like NCKU Spark, where we began considering IP and market scalability.

data.title: Moving from Prototype to Product
data.name: Dr. Keng-Jen Lin — Founder of HowHow Medical, Reviewer of “Dream Come True” Innovation Program
data.topic: Commercialization challenges, patent strategy, and research continuity
data.story: ⑤ Translation & Future Application — Moving from Prototype to Product
text: 🔹 Before the Interview

After applying for the NCKU “Dream Come True” innovation program, we wanted to refine our proposal based on reviewer feedback and real-world biotech entrepreneurship experience. Dr. Lin, both a startup founder and innovation mentor, provided guidance on how to extend the project beyond competition and start thinking like a translational researcher.
